thread.title: Sixers' undrafted Wood out to show other teams what they missed
thread.title_full: Sixers' undrafted Wood out to show other teams what they missed

author: Matt Breen,
title: Sixers' undrafted Wood out to show other teams what they missed
text:
Christian Wood wore a fancy suit with a pocket square. He and his family rented out a posh lounge of the Caesars Palace in Las Vegas. The night of June 25 belonged to him.
The UNLV product had declared for the NBA Draft two months earlier by publishing a four-minute documentary to YouTube. Wood, a 6-foot-11 power forward, expected to be a first-round choice. It was not a matter of if Wood would be drafted, it just a matter of when it would happen.
But it never did. Wood ended his draft party devastated. A picture of him with his head in his hands went viral. It was like hell, Wood said. The night, he said, still haunts his dreams.
"It hurt," Wood said. "There's not really much to say about it. I slept on it and couldn't let it weigh on me and my game. I had to move on."

Buy 76ers jerseys, memorabilia, and other gear Latest Sixers videos Wood, 20, went back to work the next morning. He then flew to Houston and latched on with the Rockets summer league squad. His play with Houston was enough to earn him a contract with the Sixers, which Wood signed in September. The draft night spurn was his motivation, Wood said. If he needed any extra incentive, Wood just had to look at his right arm.
Wood's best friend, Antwan Robertson, died when he was 13 from an asthma attack while playing basketball. The two were classmates at Pete Knight High School in Palmdale, Calif. Robertson died a few blocks from Wood's home. Wood rushed to the park as soon as he heard what happened.
After Wood declared for the draft, he found his old cell phone. Waiting there was an old text from Robertson. The last message he sent to Wood before dying read "Dream your dream with your eyes closed, but live your dream with your eyes open." Wood had the message tattooed this spring. He said his NBA pursuits are both of their dreams.
Wood enters Friday's preseason game on the bubble of making the Sixers final roster. He was able to participate in 80 percent of practice on Wednesday afternoon. A hamstring injury has kept him out of the last two games. The injury is minor, Wood said.
He has impressed the team with athleticism. Wood plays good defense and is versatile enough to play on the perimeter. Wood believes his chances to make the team "are pretty high."
"I want to show every team what they missed out on," Wood said. "I'm hustling on every loose ball. Giving it my all and giving it my 100-percent on every possession. I'm lucky to have a shot with the 76ers."
